By Lisa Shock on Thursday, June 8, 2006 - 06:39 pm:

At this point, unless MR EVO doesn't start selling this is probably going to be it for the series, Tecmo won't be willing to lose more money on a MR release.

By Blulightning on Saturday, June 10, 2006 - 12:34 am:

Lisa, I know you have much experience with Tecmo and all, but...
How can you say that!? lol...
They have yet to release Monster Rancher Jamboree, as well as their Monster Rancher Online game.
Or do you believe they will be cancelling those?
Or is it you just think they aren't going to translate the games anymore?

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, June 10, 2006 - 11:00 am:

Jamboree was shown at TGS 2004 and that's it. It was not shown at TGS 2005, and now all of the leads who were working on it are no longer with the company. It's been dropped long ago.

The Online game is being made by an outside company for Japan. It it does as poorly as MF4 and MF5 did in Japan, and MR4 and MRE sales in the US don't pick up soon, there won't be an English translation because no one will want to waste their money on it.

Look, MF5 sold so badly in Japan that the president of Tecmo's US division resigned because the company lost millions of dollars on it. The company almost had to declare bankruptcy last year. They don't have money to throw around on any sort of speculative projects, and the projects they know (MR games) have been steadily losing more and more money. Word right now is that if EVO sales don't pick up, retailers are going to pull the remaining copies from store shelves and return them for refunds next month.

By RPGDesigner on Saturday, June 10, 2006 - 11:27 am:

MR4? The game was released in late 2003. Are you sure sales for a game that age would be significant?

If so, this will make things easier for me.

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, June 10, 2006 - 05:02 pm:

Sales of MR/F4 now won't help the series. However, analysts look at those sales (lower than MRF3) and then look at sales of EVO and they see a property that is less and less worth investing in.

Honestly, if sales of the MRA games had been better, there would be some hope. But "fans" didn't even rally around these two excellent ranching games. MR/F3 broke even and that's been about the end of it. They've been trying new things to boost sales, and it hasn't worked. (and yes, MRE was made in response to all of the people who begged for an RPG -too bad most of those people haven't bothered to buy the game)

Right now, sales of EVO need to improve or that's it for North America. Japan will get the online game, which at this point is not expected to do very well, and that's it for them.

By RPGDesigner on Saturday, June 10, 2006 - 05:24 pm:

By Swezlon Uno on Saturday, July 15, 2006 - 05:58 pm:

By Lisa Shock on Sunday, July 16, 2006 - 09:16 pm:

Asking couldn't hurt, but I doubt they'd do it. Every series they have covered has individual games that have sold over a million copies, and, at the time of the show's production, had ever increasing sales.

No MR game has ever come close to selling a million copies. MR2 didn't even sell enough copies to be considered for 'Greatest Hits' status (300,000 units in the US, minimum). What the MR series looks like to an outside is a small, cult title with an ever decreasing fanbase. Every release since MR2 has had lower sales figures than the game before it. Doesn't really look like a winner. Especially with only about 30,000 people buying MR EVO. You hgave to remember that TV producers want to make money too. They are producing shows that people want to watch, because they are about popular games. In comparison with other game series' (like the ones mentioned above) MR games aren't all that popular -by about a hundred times less.

Oh yeah, it takes 6-8 months for a show to be produced and get on the air, too. That's forever in terms of game sales charts.

Really, the best way to promote the series is old-fashioned word of mouth. We've got to stay focused on selling copies.

By Sturnum94 on Wednesday, July 19, 2006 - 02:27 pm:

Lisa, would it be possible for Tecmo to try to join with a big company to try to make new games?

By MrMister on Wednesday, July 19, 2006 - 09:58 pm:

If Tecmo merged with a more successful company I would explode with joy, but I don't think it's very likely. Like, what successful game company would take such a large risk?

By Eagle Fierce on Thursday, July 20, 2006 - 10:46 am:

In all fairness, TECMO has the Ninja Gaiden series and DOA to represent for them, not to mention Fatal Frame. It seems to me that TECMO has some good titles under its belt, just that the MR series doesn't sell as well (which we all agree is saddening and mostly due to lack of exposure). TECMO is one of the few companies left that really does try to do things right, and they've always had my respect, as well as my dollar, for that. I can't imagine there wouldn't be a company willing to pick them up at some point in the future. Still, even more hoping they wouldn't have to be. I mean, if I know anything about business, once a company merges, they have to change their entire outlook and staff to correspond with the ideology of those they merged with. The last thing I want to see is TECMO losing itself to a heartless conglomerate like Square-Enix (yes, I said that). I just don't feel anything from their games anymore, and that's because any spirit they used to infuse into their games is gone. I used to consider them as a sort of goal-rival, but Square-Enix has lost my respect. Games are communication of heart and imagination, and TECMO seems to be one of the handful out there that still understand it isn't all level design and gadgets.

Just to note, it isn't much, but I've been practically browbeating all my friends to buy the MR series. I think I got on the nerves of a few of them, as I have a tendency to ramble when trying to fit info into a conversation out of left-field ^_^; Sadly, I can't guarantee any sales from any of my word of mouth, but I've developed quite a few connections in my years away, so here's to hoping.
